item.title: Coronavirus: Five and overs in UK now eligible for test
item.description: Coronavirus testing has been extended to everyone aged five and over in the UK with symptoms.

item.title: Coronavirus symptoms: UK adds loss of smell and taste to list
item.description: Loss of smell and taste join a new cough and fever as signs that self-isolation may be necessary, experts say.

item.title: Coronavirus: NI Executive agrees to lift more lockdown measures
item.description: Groups of up to six people will be allowed to meet outdoors and some sports can resume.

item.title: Coronavirus: France and Germany propose €500bn recovery fund
item.description: The countries agree a plan to distribute funds to EU member states worst affected by the pandemic.

item.title: Blackburn gun death: Victim, 19, was 'not intended target'
item.description: Law student Aya Hachem, 19, was found lying in the street near a Lidl supermarket on Sunday.

item.title: Coronavirus: Scotland aims to ease lockdown on 28 May
item.description: The moves will allow some sports and outdoor activities, and meeting someone from another household.

item.title: Coronavirus vaccine: First evidence jab can train immune system
item.description: Larger trials now needed to see if the vaccine can protect against the coronavirus.

item.title: Genette Tate disappearance: Father dies without case being solved
item.description: John Tate suspected serial child-killer Robert Black snatched his 13-year-old daughter in 1978.

item.title: Coronavirus: 6,000 jobs at risk at Cafe Rouge and Bella Italia owner
item.description: The chains' owner Casual Dining Group files intent to appoint administrators after the virus lockdown hit trading.

item.title: Coronavirus: Terminally-ill bride thanks politicians ahead of wedding
item.description: Samantha Gamble will marry on Friday after lockdown restrictions were eased by politicians last week.

item.title: Tip reopening leads to long queues
item.description: There have been huge queues since a recycling centre in Sutton Coldfield reopened.

item.title: Electric bikes 'could help people return to work'
item.description: A rise in electric-bikes would extend the range of cyclists using them to commute, a study finds.

item.title: Coronavirus pushes the RHS Chelsea Flower Show online
item.description: Exhibitors are displaying their gardens digitally in the first ever virtual version of the event.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who is behind Glasgow's Covid street art?
item.description: The pandemic has inspired a new wave of street art on the walls of Glasgow city centre.

item.title: Coronavirus: Lockdown in a migrant camp
item.description: An Afghan journalist and refugee locked down in one of Europe’s migrant camps looks at the conditions in Malakasa camp.

item.title: Coronavirus: US woman, 96, speaks Welsh for first time in 40 years
item.description: Ray McDermott, who suffers short-term memory loss, was afraid she would never speak Welsh again.

item.title: Coronavirus: Tourists flock to Southend beach as lockdown eases
item.description: Many tourists took to the east coast seaside resort as lockdown restrictions eased across England.

item.title: Luke Chadwick talks about being ridiculed for looks for Mental Health Awareness Week
item.description: Former Manchester United midfielder Luke Chadwick talks about being mocked for his looks and how it affected his mental health.

item.title: Coronavirus: Stilton sales plunge 30% amid pandemic
item.description: Makers of the UK's only trademarked cheese hope the British public will start buying more of the product.

item.title: Coronavirus: Should I start taking vitamin D?
item.description: Some people might want to consider it during the pandemic. Here's why.

item.title: Normal People decoded: Grinds, Debs and shifting
item.description: We unpack some of the Irish slang that may have passed you by in the much-loved BBC Three series.

item.title: Coronavirus: Fasting for Ramadan on the front line
item.description: What's it like to fast for Ramadan as a healthcare worker during the coronavirus pandemic?

item.title: The Great British Menu chef opening his first restaurant during lockdown
item.description: Great British Menu finalist Kray Treadwell is planning to open his debut restaurant in Birmingham in August.

item.title: Coronavirus: How have independent shopkeepers been faring?
item.description: How high street independent shops have battled to stay loyal to customers during the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'One click and we were worse off' after universal credit claim
item.description: People claiming universal credit for the first time may lose existing benefits and be worse off.

item.title: Mars: Mud flows on Red Planet behave like 'boiling toothpaste'
item.description: Scientists make a surprising discovery about the Red Planet by playing with mud in the laboratory.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'I'm not happy going back to work. It's too soon'
item.description: Nearly 5,000 people have contacted the health and safety regulator with workplace safety concerns over the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: They grabbed my breasts and said, 'You're not a woman'
item.description: Panama's lockdown allows men and women out on alternate days - but for trans people it's been tough.

item.title: How live entertainment is evolving online to be a lifeline in lockdown
item.description: Creative minds are coming up with new ideas to give us back some of the human connection we've lost.

item.title: Universities' move online 'must be done the right way'
item.description: Universities have been teaching remotely this term but can the online model work long-term?

item.title: The man who bought 60,000 oil and gas wells
item.description: Rusty Hutson Jr is the boss of fast-growing US energy firm Diversified Gas & Oil.

item.title: Afghan maternity ward attack: The woman nursing the babies of murdered mothers
item.description: Firooza Omar volunteered to nurse newborns after a deadly attack on an Afghan maternity ward.

item.title: Surprise inspections planned for Premier League clubs as training resumes from Tuesday
item.description: Clubs can expect surprise inspections during training as they prepare for the resumption of the Premier League under new safety guidelines.

item.title: Now Celtic can go for 10 in a row, says manager Lennon
item.description: Manager Neil Lennon says leading Celtic to their ninth title in a row is his best achievement in football - and he wants to top it with an unprecedented 10th consecutive championship.

item.title: Saliva on cricket balls likely to be banned - but sweat will still be allowed
item.description: Players are likely to be banned from using saliva to shine the ball by the International Cricket Council when the sport resumes after the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Callum Hudson-Odoi: Chelsea and England winger arrested and bailed
item.description: Chelsea and England winger Callum Hudson-Odoi arrested on suspicion of rape in the early hours of Sunday morning.

item.title: Tuesday's gossip: Havertz told to shun Liverpool and join Dortmund
item.description: Bayer Leverkusen's Havertz advised against joining Liverpool, Juventus set to offload Pjanic and Higuain, plus more.

item.title: Erling Braut Haaland: Hard to interview or misunderstood?
item.description: Erling Braut Haaland's interviews are earning him as many headlines as his goals are for Borussia Dotmund.

item.title: Coronavirus update: What are the symptoms of coronavirus?
item.description: The BBC’s Laura Foster explains how you can recognise the symptoms of coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk on public transport?
item.description: Bus and train operators are reducing services and increasing cleaning.

item.title: Lockdown update: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: With more restrictions eased in England on Wednesday, how will social and work life be different?

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work and is my data safe?
item.description: Millions in the UK will soon be asked to download an app that helps to limit coronavirus spreading.

item.title: Coronavirus symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: Loss of taste and smell have been added to the UK's list of coronavirus symptoms.

item.title: Coronavirus: When did care homes go into lockdown?
item.description: Many thousands of care home residents have died from coronavirus, but when were key decisions made?

item.title: Coronavirus: How long does it take to recover?
item.description: Recovery from Covid-19 can be a lengthy process, depending on how seriously people get the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Boris Johnson has announced changes to guidelines in England on exercise and social distancing.

item.title: Coronavirus: How will schools be able to reopen?
item.description: What do schools need to do to make sure they can provide a safe environment for pupils and staff.

item.title: Coronavirus: Can you start driving lessons again? And other questions
item.description: Can you start driving lessons again? and other questions answered by BBC experts.

item.title: Coronavirus: How lockdown is being lifted across Europe
item.description: As the UK alters its restrictions, how are other European countries reopening after lockdown?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should wear a face mask or face covering?
item.description: For the first time, people in England are being advised to wear face coverings in some situations.

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: How will the Covid-19 alert system work?
item.description: The threat of Covid-19 in England is to be ranked through a five-level, colour-coded alert system.

item.title: Coronavirus: How much will it cost the UK?
item.description: The pandemic will cost the government hundreds of billions of pounds. Where will it all come from?

item.title: Coronavirus: Will I be able to go on holiday?
item.description: Is it now possible to go on holiday, either in the UK or abroad?

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: Am I allowed to move house?
item.description: The easing of lockdown will affect those who want to buy or sell a home, or rent somewhere new, in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: What powers do the police have?
item.description: Police across the UK now have wide-ranging powers to help fight the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: What should I do to stop the virus spreading?
item.description: Step-by-step, what to do to help prevent the spread of the virus.

item.title: How reopened schools in Denmark keep children safely apart
item.description: What's it like in a school that has re-opened? Denmark and Germany show how it might look.

item.title: Coronavirus bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: "Bubbles" of people we can meet safely may form part of the plans to ease lockdown in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: Does lockdown easing 'follow the science'?
item.description: Why is England pressing ahead with plans to ease lockdown rules ahead of the rest of the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Millions unable to do their job due to coronavirus will have their wages paid by a new scheme.

item.title: How do I travel to work now?
item.description: Some people are being encouraged to go back to work, but how will they get there?

item.title: How to make your own face mask
item.description: Our guide to different types of face coverings and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.

item.title: Coronavirus: Do I have to go back to work after lockdown?
item.description: With lockdown restrictions eased, people may start going back to work. But what are your rights?

item.title: Coronavirus R0: What is the R number and why does it matter?
item.description: Experts keep discussing the value of R, but what is it and why does it matter?

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the UK's test, track and trace strategy?
item.description: A guide to the three key parts of the government's coronavirus strategy after lockdowns are eased.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the new travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: Intensive care and other key terms explained
item.description: Use our tool to check the meaning of key words and phrases associated with the Covid-19 outbreak.

item.title: Coronavirus: Labour's Starmer says PM statement 'raises as many questions as answers'
item.description: People are being told to go back to work without clear safety guidance, Labour leader Keir Starmer says.

item.title: Plinofficial: Russian rapper who loved dollars arrested by FBI
item.description: A cash-flaunting rapper from Siberia came to the US to become a global star. Where did it go wrong?
